Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[Xamarin.Android.Build.Tasks] Improve `javac -version` parsing" (#1292) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
The [Ubuntu build][0] is [failing][1]:

	warning : Failed to get the Java SDK version as it does not appear to contain a valid version number.
	`javac -version` returned:
	```openjdk version "1.8.0_03-Ubuntu"
	OpenJDK Runtime Environment (build 1.8.0_03-Ubuntu-8u77-b03-3ubuntu3-b03)
	OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM (build 25.03-b03, mixed mode)
	```
	...
	Task "AdjustJavacVersionArguments"
	  …/bin/Debug/lib/xamarin.android/xbuild/Xamarin/Android/Xamarin.Android.Common.targets:
	  error : Error executing task AdjustJavacVersionArguments: Required property 'JdkVersion' not set.

[0]: https://jenkins.mono-project.com/view/Xamarin.Android/job/xamarin-android-linux/779/
[1]: https://jenkins.mono-project.com/view/Xamarin.Android/job/xamarin-android-linux/779/consoleText

This was introduced/broken by commit 0e1d1c8a, which turned
`AdjustJavacVersionArguments.JdkVersion` into a `[Required]`
parameter. The value for `AdjustJavacVersionArguments.JdkVersion`
comes from the `<ResolveSdks/>` task `JdkVersion` output parameter,
which itself comes from parsing `javac -version` output.

The problem is that the regex we used to parse the output of
`javac -version` wasn't properly parsing the output on Ubuntu:

	openjdk version "1.8.0_03-Ubuntu"

Specifically, the `-Ubuntu` text was causing the regex to not match.

Update the regex to be a bit more lenient, enabling it to work with
the Ubuntu `javac -version` output, which *should* allow the build to
progress further.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[build] fix api-xml-adjuster.targets on Windows" (#1291) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Since 7d705bf, the Windows builds on VSTS have seemed to be failing. I
tested this locally, and noticed the use of command line arguments such
as:

    -parameter-names='%(SomeVariable)'

Unfortunately, this isn't working on Windows due to the single quote. It
is more appropriately expressed as:

    -parameter-names="%(SomeVariable)"

This isn't very pretty, but it should work on all platforms.

I also fixed all the tabs I saw in this file--in favor of spaces, and
fixed other XML code conventions.

I will now return to my regularly scheduled baby duty.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[Xamarin.Android.Build.Tasks] Add GetAndroidDependencies Target" (#1290) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Fixes #1269

This commit adds the `GetAndroidDependencies` target to the
`Xamarin.Android.Common.targets`. Its purpose is to examine
the various settings in the project and report which android
sdk build-tools, platform-tools etc are required.

`GetAndroidDependencies` will output an @(AndroidDependency)
with Version metadata Valid component names are platform,
build-tool, platform-tool and tool.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[Xamarin.Android.Build.Tasks] Add Support for CodeBehind for layout files" (#1238) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Closed issue "How to Exclude default material icons from Xamarin.Android Apk?" (#1288) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
I unzipped my apk and in res folder there many sub folders as shown below and each folder has icons which are not part of my project as shown in the 2nd image. At least they arent in my source code. I dont know where they are coming from. Probably Xamarin.Android includes them as default material icons. But I am using my own svg icons as embedded resources in my PCL project and I dont need those pngs to be part of my apk. They just bloat and increase size of my apk (even though probably 1-2mb max.)

How can I exclude or remove those? I am already using full linking and proguard in my xamarin.android project.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10422347/36021825-535fbf8c-0d87-11e8-81a7-151d4399740c.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10422347/36021837-57d134f6-0d87-11e8-9716-bde7faf0cfdb.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Add ProgressColor on ProgressBar" (#1861) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description of Change ###

This PR adds the `ProgressColor` bindable property to the ProgressBar control.

### Bugs Fixed ###

 - None

### API Changes ###

Added:
 - Color ProgressBar.ProgressColor { get; set; } //Bindable Property

Changed:
 - None

### Behavioral Changes ###

 - None

### PR Checklist ###

- [x] Has tests (if omitted, state reason in description)
- [x] Rebased on top of master at time of PR
- [x] Changes adhere to coding standard
- [x] Consolidate commits as makes sense

### Supported Platforms ###

- [x] Android
- [x] iOS
- [x] UWP
- [x] WPF
- [x] macOS
- [x] Tizen
- [ ] GTK

### Remarks ###

 - On Android API 21+, `ColorStateList` is used instead of `SetColorFilter` in order to apply the color tinting to the progress line only
 - NOP on GTK due to some constraints when overriding the default GtkWidget style
 - Not every platform exposes APIs to change the track appearance. Shouldn't the TrackColor feature be implemented in a custom-specific fashion?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Forms][Android][custom rendrerer]android.widget.LinearLayout cannot be cast to android.widget.ImageView" (#1860) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues

### Description
in Xamarin Forms, I have a content page, inside it, I have an image with gesture recognise like following,

```
<Image Grid.Row="0" Grid.Column="1" Source="Share.png">
  <Image.GestureRecognizers>
    <TapGestureRecognizer Tapped="TapGestureRecognizer_Tapped_2"></TapGestureRecognizer>
  </Image.GestureRecognizers>
</Image>
```

In android project, I have a custom renderer to make the Taps on tabbed page in bottom, so When I call
the following function:
```
if (Platform.GetRenderer (view) == null) {
  Platform.SetRenderer (view, Platform.CreateRenderer (view));
}
```
the following exception is thrown
`Java.Lang.ClassCastException: android.widget.LinearLayout cannot be cast to android.widget.ImageView`

when I remove the Gesture Recogniser, the exception is not thrown any more,
note that this issue happened only after I updated Xamarin.Forms from version 2.3.3.193 to version
2.5.0.122203


### Steps to Reproduce

1. following the description above
2. 
3. 

### Expected Behavior
no exception thrown
### Actual Behavior
the following exception is thrown:
`Java.Lang.ClassCastException: android.widget.LinearLayout cannot be cast to android.widget.ImageView`
### Basic Information

- Version with issue:
- Last known good version:
- IDE: vs2017 community 15.5.6
- Platform Target Frameworks: <!-- All that apply -->

  - Android: 7.1 
  - UWP:  <!-- The version of the UWP SDK you are compiling against, e.g. 16299 --> 
- Android Support Library Version: 27.0.3
- Nuget Packages:
- Affected Devices:
all android devices
### Screenshots

<!-- If the issue is a visual issue, please include screenshots showing the problem if possible -->

### Reproduction Link

<!-- Please upload or provide a link to a reproduction case -->

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Vertical slider takes horizontal space as length" (#1858) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description
In short, 90 degree rotated Slider elements are limited in height to their available horizontal space (and perhaps this is true for other objects, too).

The issue I have encountered is the same as the one in this forum post:
https://forums.xamarin.com/discussion/69180/vertical-slider-takes-horizontal-space-as-lenght
While the forum post provides some example code, I've created my own below for even easier reproduction.

### Code to Reproduce

```
<Grid>
    <Grid.ColumnDefinitions>
        <ColumnDefinition Width="30*" />
        <ColumnDefinition Width="70*" />
    </Grid.ColumnDefinitions>
    <Grid.RowDefinitions>
        <RowDefinition Height="50*"/>
        <RowDefinition Height="50*"/>
    </Grid.RowDefinitions>
    <BoxView Color="DarkBlue"/>
    <BoxView Color="DarkCyan" Grid.Column="1"/>
    <BoxView Color="Yellow" Grid.Row="1"/>
    <BoxView Color="DarkGreen" Grid.Column="1" Grid.Row="1"/>
    <Slider Grid.Row="1" Maximum="100" Minimum="0" Value="100" Rotation="-90"
          VerticalOptions="Center" />
</Grid>
```
![xamarinverticalslider](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1504620/36065553-30737f50-0e62-11e8-84c2-1d57de12c759.png)

Related Bug: If **VerticalOptions="Center"** is removed (defaulting to **Fill**), the handle of the slider detaches from the body of the slider.
![xamarinverticalsliderdetached](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1504620/36065566-4ca340b6-0e62-11e8-85e5-dd15afe8903b.png)

Related Bug: Adding any left or right **Margin** (such as "50,0,0,0") also has a non-intuitive effect where the _height_ of the rotated slider is reduced by the margin _and_ the slider moves left or right as expected.
![xamarinverticalsliderwithleftmargin](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1504620/36065568-516ee172-0e62-11e8-9256-5a2d1e2ebd3e.png)

### Expected Behavior
Available space and Slider dimensions should be calculated _after_ the rotation is applied so that a vertically rotated Slider can expand to the Height of its container, Margins are sanely handled, etc.

### Actual Behavior
Available space is calculated before rotation, imposing non-intuitive limitations on element position and size after rotation, only allowing a Height which is at maximum only as large as the Width of its container.

### Basic Information
- Version with issue: Xamarin.Forms 2.5
- Last known good version: N/A
- IDE: Visual Studio 2017
- Platform Target Frameworks: <!-- All that apply -->
  - iOS:  Not yet testing
  - Android: 4.4 (API 19) running on Visual Studio Emulator for Android
  - UWP:  Not yet testing 
- Android Support Library Version: N/A
- Nuget Packages: None (besides standard Xamarin.Forms)
- Affected Devices: Virtual and Physical

### Screenshots
See above for screen shots in context.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[rfc] Simpler fix for missing [DesignatedInitializer] for default constructors" (#3247) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

Check xtro results, e.g. https://jenkins.mono-project.com/job/xamarin-macios-pr-builder/5958/Extrospection_Report/

### Expected Behavior

No entry with `!missing-designated-initializer!` :)

### Actual Behavior

Many entries, but largely ones for default `.ctor` (or `init`), e.g.

```
!missing-designated-initializer! NSCell::init is missing an [DesignatedInitializer] attribute
```

This, right now, takes a bit of time to fix because it requires more work like https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-macios/pull/3142/files i.e. disabling the default constructor, defining it manually and add `[DesignatedInitializer]` (4 line change per type).

### Potential Solution

Modify the `[DesignatedInitializer]` attributes, as used in bindings (not the platform assemblies), to be usable on types, e.g. bindings like:

```
	[BaseType (typeof (NSObject))]
	[DesignatedInitializer]
	interface NSCell { ... }
```

would generate a:

```
		[Export ("init")]
		[DesignatedInitializer]
		public NSCell () : base (NSObjectFlag.Empty) { ... }
```

instead of the current:

```
		[Export ("init")]
		public NSCell () : base (NSObjectFlag.Empty) { ... }
```

### Notes

The `DesignatedInitializerAttribute` attribute (in the platform assemblies) would still remain decorated with:

```
[AttributeUsage (AttributeTargets.Constructor | AttributeTargets.Method)]
```

only the version used for bindings/generator would accept the attribute on types.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[generator] Add support for [DesignatedInitializer]. Fix #3247" (#3451) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
Add an easier syntax for automatically generated default .ctor/init
what needs to be decorated with `[DesignatedInitializer]`.

The current way of doing this requires a bit too much work.
More details in:
https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-macios/issues/3247

Generator diff: https://gist.github.com/spouliot/2675be8ce15ab473ed7c573403d7eb47

Note that this includes the Foundation and UIKit fixes (reported
by xtro). Those will be committed separately once this is merged.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[generator] Reuse the [RequiresSuper] attribute from the platform assemblies." (#3453) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
Bindings trying to override members with that attribute would produce a

```
error BI1055: bgen: Internal error: failed to convert type 'ObjCRuntime.RequiresSuperAttribute, Xamarin.iOS, Version=0.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=84e04ff9cfb79065'. Please file a bug report (https://bugzilla.xamarin.com) with a test case.
```

Fixes https://github.com/xamarin/maccore/issues/632
